DOC.HEAD: Scholarly Minister Drives School Bus
DOC.TEXT: When the Rev. C. Michael Thornburg, Anglican scholar and rector of Christ Church, turned to his ultimate boss with a plea for help out of a financial bind, he didn't expect such a quick respone. Thornburg said he prayed, ``You got me into this, now get me out.'' Thirty minutes later, Harold D. Hayes, one of the contractors who provides bus service for the Southern Berkshire Regional School District knocked on the rectory door and a second career was born. Twice each school day Thornburg takes the wheel of a big yellow school bus in this little Berkshire Hills town. ``This has turned out to be one of the best parts of being in Sheffield,'' he said recently. He described his unusual second job as the answer to his prayers on how to to keep three chldren in college on a clergyman's stipend. Thornburg, armed with a B.A., an M.A., a divinity degree and a Ph.D., hired on to drive 55 children grades K-12 over the rural New England hills. The expert on the history of the Anglican Church and the Reformation sees it as a challenge that goes beyond keeping an close eye on icy roads. ``I'm the first adult the children see outside their homes each morning,'' he said. ``I affect in some small way how they feel about themselves entering the day.'' Of course, he said. ``I don't hesitate to yell at them and tell them to sit down.''
